blocks.content:
Welcome to LogQL 101.

In this guide you will learn how to:

- Select a Loki data source in Explore
- Write basic LogQL queries using label selectors
- Refine results with line filters and JSON parsing
- Make results easier to scan with formatting
- Avoid common pitfalls when converting logs to metrics

## Section 1: Write your first LogQL query ‚úçÔ∏è

What you will learn in this section:

- Select the data source used by this guide
- Set the time range intentionally for your queries
- Write a label selector, run a query, and view results

blocks.tooltip: Select the data source used by this guide.
blocks.content: Select **LokiNGINXLogs** in the Data source menu.

blocks.tooltip: Log results are always scoped to the selected time range. Pick a range intentionally so you know what time window your query is searching.
blocks.content: Open the time range menu (clock icon), then select **Last 15 minutes**.

blocks.tooltip: Use Code mode to type LogQL directly.
blocks.content: Select **Code** mode.

blocks.tooltip: Run the query to see matching log lines.
blocks.content:
Type a label selector query:

`{service_name="nginx_access_log"}`

blocks.tooltip: This runs your query using the current time range and data source selection.
blocks.content: Click **Run query** (play icon).

blocks.tooltip: This area shows the results for your last query.
blocks.content: Notice the results area. If you see many lines, that‚Äôs normal‚Äîstart with labels, then narrow with filters.

### What you have learned

- How to select a Loki data source
- How to change the time range used for queries
- How to start with a label selector
- How to run a query and view results

## Section 2: Refine results with line filters üîé

What you will learn in this section:

- How to narrow results using line filters
- Why line filters can match more than you expect

blocks.tooltip: Line filters match text anywhere in each log line.
blocks.content:
Add a label and a simple line filter, then run the query:

`{service_name="nginx_access_log", host="appfelstrudel"} |= "500"`
If this feels noisy: `|= "500"` matches any log line containing that text, not ‚ÄúHTTP status is 500‚Äù. Next we‚Äôll make it more precise.

blocks.tooltip: Combining include and exclude filters can reduce noise.
blocks.content:
Exclude a common success code, then run the query:

`{service_name="nginx_access_log", host="appfelstrudel"} |= "500" != "200"`

### What you have learned

- How to use line filters to narrow results
- Why line filters can match more than you expect

## Section 3: Parse JSON for precise filtering üß©

What you will learn in this section:

- How to parse JSON logs
- How to filter by a specific field

blocks.tooltip: Parsing structured logs lets you filter by fields instead of raw text.
blocks.content:
Parse JSON and filter by the `status` field, then run the query:

`{service_name="nginx_access_log", host="appfelstrudel"} | json | status = "500"`

### What you have learned

- How to parse JSON logs
- How to filter by a specific field

## Section 4: Format output with line_format üßπ

What you will learn in this section:

- How to format each log line for easier scanning

blocks.tooltip: Formatting changes how results display without changing which lines match.
blocks.content:
Add `line_format` and run the query:

`{service_name="nginx_access_log", host="appfelstrudel"} | json | status = "500" | line_format "{{.status}} {{.request_uri}}"`

### What you have learned

- How to format each log line for easier scanning

## Section 5: Use regex carefully üßµ

What you will learn in this section:

- How to apply regex to a specific parsed field
- When to avoid regex

blocks.tooltip: Regex on a specific field is more precise than regex on the full line.
blocks.content:
Match only URIs that include an ID segment, then run the query:

`{service_name="nginx_access_log", host="appfelstrudel"} | json | status = "500" | request_uri =~ ".*/id/[0-9]+.*" | line_format "{{.status}} {{.request_uri}}"`
Tip: `!~` is the exclude form. For example: `| request_uri !~ "/admin"`.

### What you have learned

- How to apply regex to a specific parsed field
- Why regex should be a last resort

## Section 6: Turn logs into a chart üìà

What you will learn in this section:

- How to count matching log lines over time
- How to avoid common series limit errors

blocks.tooltip: This turns a log query into a time series by counting matches over time.
blocks.content:
Count HTTP 500s over time, then run the query:

`count_over_time({service_name="nginx_access_log", host="appfelstrudel"} | json | status = "500"[1h])`
If you hit a series limit error, it‚Äôs usually because parsing creates many unique series. To fix it, aggregate everything into a single series with `sum()`.

blocks.tooltip: Aggregating reduces series count by combining many series into one.
blocks.content:
Wrap the query with `sum()` and run it:

`sum(count_over_time({service_name="nginx_access_log", host="appfelstrudel"} | json | status = "500"[1h]))`

### What you have learned

- How to count log matches over time
- How to reduce series cardinality with aggregation

## Wrap up

A practical LogQL workflow is:

- Start with labels to narrow the search
- Add line filters to refine
- Prefer parsing for precision
- Format results to scan quickly
- Use regex only when you can‚Äôt parse
- Aggregate when turning logs into metrics
